Step-by-Step Guide

First things first, growing out a pixie undercut takes time and patience. It can take anywhere from 6 months to a year to grow out your hair to shoulder length. So, be patient and don't give up!

2. Trim Your Hair Regularly

Trimming your hair regularly, every 6-8 weeks, will help to promote healthy hair growth and prevent split ends. By trimming your hair, you'll also be able to shape your hair as it grows out, making the transition easier.

item.title: How To Put Really Short Hair Up A Step By Step Guide
item.description:

Before we get into the specific styles, let’s talk about some general tips for putting really short hair up:

Sleek Low Bun

This is a classic and elegant style that works well for both formal and casual occasions.

Step 1: Brush your hair back and gather it into a low ponytail at the nape of your neck.

Step 2: Twist the ponytail tightly and wrap it around the base to create a bun.

Step 3: Secure the bun with bobby pins, making sure to hide them as much as possible.

Step 4: Smooth down any flyaways with hairspray or a bit of gel.

If you’re going for a more relaxed look, a messy updo is a great option.

Step 1: Create a deep side part.

Step 2: Take a small section of hair on the side with less hair and twist it back, securing it with a bobby pin behind your ear.

Step 4: Use a bit of hairspray to hold everything in place.

  4. The hairstylist will remove the perm rods and style the hair as desired.

  5. Apply the perm solution to each section of hair, making sure to saturate the hair evenly.
  6. Cover your hair with a plastic cap and let it process for the recommended amount of time.
  7. Rinse your hair thoroughly with warm water and remove the perm rods.
  8. Apply the neutralizer to your hair and let it process for the recommended amount of time.

The top layer of your hair is the part that is most exposed to the elements, such as sun, wind, and heat. This layer can become damaged over time, which can affect its ability to curl. How to Determine the Cause

Before you can fix the issue, you need to determine the cause. Here are some things to consider:

Hair Type

People with straight or wavy hair may struggle to get the top layer of their hair to curl, as the hair is naturally resistant to curling. If you have curly hair, but the top layer is straight, it could be a sign of damage or a different curl pattern.

Styling Methods

The way you style your hair can also affect its ability to curl. Using a lot of heat styling tools, such as flat irons or curling irons, can damage the hair and make it harder to curl. Hair Damage

If the top layer of your hair is damaged, it may not curl as well as the rest of your hair. Damage can occur from heat styling, chemical treatments, or even brushing your hair too aggressively. Look for signs of damage, such as split ends or breakage.

Cut Your Hair

Change Your Styling Methods

Avoid using heat styling tools as much as possible. If you must use them, use a heat protectant and keep the temperature low. Use lightweight products and make sure to detangle your hair before styling.

  • Forehead: Measure across the widest part of your forehead, from one temple to the other.
  • Cheekbones: Measure across your cheekbones, starting from the outer corner of your eye to the edge of your nose.
  • Jawline: Measure from the tip of your chin to the point below your ear where your jaw angles upward.

  • Triangle: Jawline measures greater than cheekbones, which measure larger than forehead.
